text: oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for an album review Shabazz Palaces
black up right there sitting there gonna
be there all week
okay Beirut is a project spearheaded by
multi-instrumentalist Zac Condon and
this is his third LP third full-length
LP under the project the riptides so
Beirut when I first came into this band
it was pretty exciting because around
that time in college a professor of mine
had recently introduced me to Balkan
brass music gypsy music Romanian music
klezmer and ever since then I've had
kind of a soft spot for that stuff and
anything that you know kind of tries to
be like it the kind of sounds that that
bands like a hawk and a hacksaw recreate
so lovingly and so well it's not new for
a western band to be kind of toying with
this sort of stuff but Beirut to me was
a little bit different in that Zac
Condon really wanted to write pop songs
but was still so in love still so
enamored with this sound and style it
just had to be incorporated into his
music he seemed really like kind of
dedicated to the origins of this kind of
stuff and making that really clear in
his music I mean he even collaborated
with one of mine and and I'm sure there
one of his favorite Balkan brass bands
the cocaine II orcas star if you check
out B roots first record gulag workers
star there's just a mood there that
isn't usually there in western music
with the really weepy horns and
accordion and and strings and piano just
just really weepy really mournful I
don't mean sad I don't mean depressed
I mean mourning and Zach took that sound
and really just like translated and
translated it for a Western audience
there were poppier
on that album like postcards from Italy
but that stuff wasn't the the main event
for me the main event the majority of
the stuff on there really had deep roots
in that Eastern European flavor then
after that came the Flying Club Cup in
2007 and there was a change there
the songs seemed a little simpler a
little poppier but it resulted in catchy
ER songs
something that was a little more
immediate plus the recording was better
there were some awesome string
arrangements on there from Owen Pallett
and it just seemed like the natural
progression past gulag things fell
silent for a little bit and then Zack
dropped these 2 EPS together real people
Holland and March of the zapotec real
people Holland was something from
another solo project of Zacks which was
really more of an electrified indie pop
sound but March of the zapotec achieved
something that I always wanted to happen
for Beirut a really gigantic huge live
hit Orchestra sized horn section not
multitrack horns thrown together in a
studio real actual horn section playing
arrangements and songs that he's putting
together perfect recording and great
musicianship just bringing it all
together for just a massive and
emotional set of songs and now we're
here with the Riptide and I can't help
but feel like we've moved backwards just
a little bit those 2 EPS that Zac
released in 2009 they were on such
opposite ends of this spectrum that it
was hard to love both of them but now
after I hear this I can I can hear why
he wanted to print both of them because
his love of really simplified pop music
comes on strong with the Riptide in
comparison with the Flying Club Cup and
Gulag orca star this thing comes to the
table with less less detail in the
arrangements less length less foreign
flavor and less energy it's hard for me
to feel that way and be happy you know
what I mean
the songs on this are simple and the
songs on the Flying Club cup are simple
too but the trade-off on that album was
that you know the songs are simple but
the Arrangements come on heavy
they're everywhere they're intricate
they're very layered and there's always
something new you could pull out of them
making it worth it to return to this
album and listen to it again and again
and again they're still horn sections on
here but none of them weep none of them
really a Moute
none of them Papa they just all kind of
fly in between verses to to just break
things up a little bit East Harlem
vagabond Santa Fe Zak's horns have
kicked more butt than this they have
they have and you know I can appreciate
simpler simpler is cool but these
heftier horn arrangements these heftier
instrumental passengers haven't been
replaced with anything the songs just
feel a little neutered most of the
tracks on here just consist of of
several different chords I mean the
first two songs pretty much had the same
chord progression but in different keys
the same chord progression in a
different key that is used behind the
song Nantes on the Flying Club cup this
thing isn't entirely bad though I still
dig Zacks vocals a lot and the songs I
gravitate toward the most are the ones
where he's digging into that a lot his
vocals his singing on port of call is
great I love his emotion on that and
hearing him sing over that pump organ
drone I assume it's a pump organ on the
peacock is really dramatic too still all
the instruments are on this album just
like they used to be there was a little
bit of a flash of indie pop flavor here
and there like on the song Santa Fe with
the with the bouncing synthesizers that
open up the track and for the most part
the music here still implies stuff like
baguettes and wine and candlelit dinners
on the balconies of of expensive and
fancy five-star hotels and Downton Abbey
it's just that to me the riptides is
like a night in Paris
whereas flying Club Cup is like a week
and gulag work as stars like a year
backpacking through Europe visiting
every country that you possibly can
still this thing is a beirut album I
would rather listen to this and I feel
more definition
in this than any number of low fire or
synth-pop bands who all sound the same
but I still can't help but feel like
I've heard this done before better by
this project I'm feeling a strong five
to a light six on this what did you guys
think of it love it hate it why but what
does Cal two just think u.s.a u.s.a
u.s.a u.s.a forever
